724382f-b.text:
West Broadway, east side, south from a point slightly north of White Street and showing at the N.E. corner a amall 2istory frame house With a metal sheath. Appearing overhead are the tracks of the Sixth Ave.
Elevated line.
May 2, 1938.
P. L. Sperr.
The same location after demolition of the Sixth Avenue "E1'.
May 19, 1939
P. L. Sperr

724381f-a.text:
217 West Broadway, east side, between White and Franklin Streets.
Tiis is a frame house with a stucco front.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Puseum of the City of New York
Negative No. 605.
724381f-a.folder: West Broadway & White Street, Manhattan, NY

724384f-a.text:
West Broadway, west side, south from North Moore Street, showing across the Sixth Ave. Elevated structure the Western Union Building outline. Note in the foreground, the Franklin Street station at Finn Square. It is at the latter point where Varick Street starts, diverging
northward from West Broadway.
May 2, 1938.
P. L. Sperr.
The same Locale, subseouent to 'El' demolition.
July 12, 1939
P. L. Sperr
724384f-a.folder: West Broadway & North Moore Street, Manhattan, NY

northward from West Broadway.

724385f-b.text:
West Broadway, west side, north from North Moore to Beach Streeti At the N.W. corner of North Moore Street is a group of 3-story frame structurei with brick fronts. These are No's. 1 and 3 North Moore Street and 242 and 244
West Broadway.
The corner building bears two of these identities (No. 1 and 242). The two story feature, centered in View 2, is of brick construction. This bears No. 246 West Broadway and adjoina the 6-story loft building, No. 248-50 (also 2-4-6
Beach Street).
July 12, 1939
View 1, 2
P. L. Sperr
724385f-b.folder: West Broadway & North Moore Street, Manhattan, NY
724385f-b.original_title: Manhattan: West Broadway - North Moore Street

724383f-b.text:
West Broadway, east side, north from White Street, showing prominently the 2k story frame building at the N. E. corner. These 3 views are more or less similar; one be'ng more inclusive in a vertical plane, to show the dominant N. Y. Telephone Building. This towering edifice is st the convergence of sixth Avenue South and
Church Street.
View 1:1932
J. Clarence Davies Collection
Museum of N. Y.
Negative No. 548
View 2: September 9, 1928
View 3: July 12, 1939
P. L. Sperr
724383f-b.folder: West Broadway & White Street, Manhattan, NY
